title: Fuel Cells and Clean Energy
scenario: An engineering team is developing a hydrogen fuel cell for electric vehicles. They need to understand the electrochemistry and optimise efficiency.
content:
A hydrogen fuel cell is a galvanic cell that converts chemical energy directly to electrical energy with high efficiency. At the anode: H₂ → 2H⁺ + 2e⁻ (oxidation). At the cathode: O₂ + 4H⁺ + 4e⁻ → 2H₂O (reduction). Overall: 2H₂ + O₂ → 2H₂O, E°cell = +1.23 V.

Unlike combustion engines (~25% efficiency), fuel cells achieve 40–60% electrical efficiency. The Nernst equation describes how actual cell potential varies with hydrogen and oxygen concentrations (partial pressures).
guided_questions: Write the half-reactions at the anode and cathode of a hydrogen fuel cell.
Using ΔG = −nFE°, calculate the maximum work extractable from the reaction 2H₂ + O₂ → 2H₂O at standard conditions.
How does the Nernst equation predict cell voltage when H₂ partial pressure is reduced to 0.5 atm?
what_you_learned: Fuel cells demonstrate electrochemistry in action — galvanic cell principles, the Nernst equation, and Gibbs free energy calculations describe clean energy conversion with higher efficiency than combustion.
